@Ben Gibson  What I wrote was concise and correct. It's not my fault if the person reading it doesn't have the comprehension skills to understand it.

@Wallart pops Your certain standard and level of journalistic integrity has nothing to do with what you suggested should be law. Again, you do not realise what you are saying, it does not result in what you say you want.

@Ben Gibson No, what's truly absurd is your apparent belief that print media SHOULDN'T have to be held to a certain standard or maintain a respectable level of journalistic integrity. News outlets have a code of ethics they are supposed to abide by, which includes using reputable sources, checking facts and getting comments from people on BOTH SIDES of an issue. 
It's true that a defamation lawsuit can be brought against a news outlet that printed a story that they knew was false but it's not the only reason. People can also sue for defamation if it can be proven that a news outlet showed a "reckless disregard" for whether or not the article they were publishing was true. Considering what was written about Johnny Depp and what has since come out about Amber Heard and the many lies she has told, I'd say that criteria has easily been met.
